The massacre of Srebrenica is unfortunately known to too few people - but above all, most people do not have on their radar how relatively recently this tragedy of July 11, 1995 occurred. In Quo Vadis, Aida? we follow Aida, a teacher working for the United Nations as a translator in a UN protection camp with a thousand citizens. Thanks to her work, Aida believes that she and her family are safe from the genocide taking place outside the camp. However, she gets to feel in a brutal way that a war knows no justice.

The plot always focuses on protagonist Aida (Jasna Duricic) and her iron will to bring her family to protection. Because no one is prioritized in such an exceptional situation, Aida often does not get what she wants. Yet she was hoping for exactly this consequence due to her special position as a translator. This results in some heated discussions and arguments with UN commanders and soldiers, who regularly refuse Aida's wishes. Duricic especially succeeds in this role in drawing the audience to her side and making them suffer with Aida. Of course, her actions are perfectly legitimate and it's frustrating every time to see her rebuffed. As an audience member, on the other hand, it's difficult to put ourselves in this situation. After all, for the most part, we have no idea what these struggles for survival in war feel like. Accordingly, it's not my place to judge the characters' behaviors, which don't seem particularly ethical to us. As much tension and back-and-forth tugging as this caused in me, unfortunately Duricic couldn't quite reach me emotionally. The nightmare she personally finds herself in with her family, and especially the mission to deliver bad news to the suffering survivors, can't be beat for incomprehension and emotional weight. However, I always felt as if the actress was always in a certain stage of empathy and self-pity that she couldn't get out of for the entire film. To me, there's a bit of a lack of breakthrough below that surface, where you could have bought into her suffering even more. Sure, she has scenes where she has outbursts and comes out of her equilibrium. However, these have been in short supply and once they are due, they are either too short or lack emotional impact for me.

This is one of the few criticisms I can give the film. But even in this respect, it would not trigger enough emotions in me, it is successful in the end. Because I left the cinema with a heavy blow in the pit of my stomach and struggled for composure and words because of the, not really unpredictable, outcome. The subject matter sits too deep for that and leaves a layman, who was lucky enough not to have had to experience a war yet, shocked. Besides the fact how recently the event happened and the geographical proximity, I would have wished for some more impressions and information about Srebrenica. Thus, Quo Vadis, Aida? is not really a war film, but rather a character study that creates an eerie and authentic atmosphere.
Acting was so good I thought I was watching a documentary at times.  On the edge of my seat.

So horrible so horrible…

A war movie about the Srebrenica massacre in 1995. A mother, who's also an interpreter, tried to get her family to safety while the civilians were being transported by the Serbian force. 

Coming in, I didn't know anything about the real life story. However, after watching about 10 to 15 minutes, it was abundantly clear what was going to happen. For the rest of the movie, it became a desperate, maddening, and heartbreaking descend into the inevitable. This was shown through the lens of our main character, and her desperation was relatable, like if you were in her shoes you would do everything she did. 

The color and cinematography also heightened the desperation. The movie looked monotonous. The overwhelming color of the ground during the day felt hot, dry, and reflected the dire situation the civilians were in. Even more, the movie felt so raw, making me feel like I'm actually there with the people. 

And then the ending hit. I knew it was coming, but still I was in silence as the camera slowly moved away. There's no need for showing actual violence. Just the sound was enough to convey the horror. The last scene was a strong testament of the director about the unjust event.

Overall, a devastating movie that i would not want to see again. 9/10

This too is what human beings do. Again we see the unconscionable inhumane acts of the subhumans in this setting. An attempt at some sort of genocide by murdering all these men? The tension is set from the start and maintained throughout. Again we see the complete ineffectual uselessness of military officers who sit, thumbs up their asses, while the enemy lies, manipulates, then slaughters with no conscience whatsoever. 3.7 stars

An intense and very tragic war drama that features a powerful performance by Djasna Djuricic, who plays a woman who's trying to stay calm while desperately trying to keep her family safe during the Bosnian War.

Jasmila Žbanić wrote, directed and produced a riveting and heart wrenching drama that is held in place by the brilliantly locked in performance of Jasna Đuričić.  The film, of Bosnia and Herzegovina origin, tells the true story of the genocide in that country and how it forever changed the existence of the country and its people.  It's a hard watch, but one that never lets go of your conscious or your brain.  It's one I'll be thinking about for quite some time and how can you not.  Even though you know where the story is going it's told in such a way that you're totally engaged.  One of the best films of 2020.  Final Score: 9.7/10

This film is heartache, especially since it is based on real events. Every moment is tense and filled with human fighting-spirit, thanks to excellent writing, directing, and performances. A direly important film!! The fact that this did not win the Best International Film Oscar is downright infuriating!

Oscar nominated foreign film that follows a UN translator that is attempting to keep her family safe during the Bosnian War... the film tells the events preceding the Srebrenica massacre.... Heartbreaking story well told in this film.

The story of the events on July 11th, 1995 that lead to unimaginable tragedy in Bosnian town of Srebrenica, is mostly shown through the eyes of Aida (Jasna Djuricic), a UN translator who tries everything to protect her family from the enemy forces while doing her job. In this emotional tour de force it's almost impossible not to root for Aida or not to feel irritated by the UN forces incompetence. Kudos to director/writer Jasmila Zbanic, who did an extensive research and based her movie even on some real life dialogs (involving general Mladic), captured on camera. This war drama - masterfully evoking the event that never should've happened, spreads the universal message of the mother's love for her family and the human resilience in the toughest situations - is a must see for all movie fans around the world.

This historical film is based on the massacre of thousands of men and boys in an ethnic cleansing operation in Bosnia in the mid-1990s. The event is told through the experience of Aida, a translator for the United Nations peacekeeping forces assigned to monitor a temporary cease-fire between the Bosnian Serbs and the Bosnian Muslims. Aria knows more about what is going on and what is about to happen, but she finds herself torn between the needs of her people and the activities of the UN overseers as well as the need to save her sons and husband. The direction and screenplay are excellent, as is the performance of the lead actress who plays Aida. The film captures well the "fog of war" and the chaos that results from the UN's botched efforts at maintaining peace. Since I am not very familiar with this part of history, I read about the event before watching the film. Even knowing the outcome, the film pulsed with energy and dread as Aida frantically tries to figure out the right path forward. I loved the film. It is sleek and never meanders from the main theme and well-acted. It is also a heartbreaking examination of the personal impact of war and genocide. Big thumbs up from me. This is Bosnia and Herzegovina's entry for the Oscars this year, and it is well-deserving of the nod.

A Different take on a war movie, that puts emotion first. It happens in a historically accurate setting but doesn't loose itself in details and facts, it offers just enough for you to follow and a starting point for further research. 
Direction is on a world level and visual storytelling incredibly powerful, enforced by great performances.

This movie provides a moving glimpse into the Srebrenica massacre from the perspective of Aida, a Bosnian translator working for the U.N. Aida is rational yet passionate in her cautiously optimistic endeavours to save her husband and two sons from the Serbian soldiers hungry for revenge following the occupation of Srebrenica. Beautifully shot scenes paint all shades of dark in human soul such as despair, fear, cruelty and revenge. This impressive movie about one of the most shameful chapters of European history is a must see.
A harrowing drama and and an infuriating history.
It's a very bad movie. Awful storytelling, awful acting, horrible photography and storytelling. For me, the director clearly doesn't know how to make a movie and the aesthetics of filmmaking.
Quo Vadis, Aida? is superbly executed by writer-director Jasmila Žbanić, whose unflinching eye captures the horror of the war with searing details.
Fantastic from beginning to end, the movie creates tension and portraits an shocking historic event, with an outstanding lead performance from Jasna Đuričić. QUO VADIS, AIDA? 10.0

Quo Vadis, Aida? is a powerful story told very well. Jasna Đuričić was absolutely excellent. The emotion in her performance was just amazing. I knew nothing about the real world events that this film is based on, and I feel like that’s a problem. A lot more people should know this story. This is a difficult watch that is bolstered by top tier filmmaking and acting. Overall, I thought this was a great film. It’s a very important story told very well, and it definitely deserved its Oscar nomination. I recommend checking this one out.
This is Masterpiece!

Excellent movie done in collaboration by producers and actors from all over Europe. However, I actually think the horrors and the destruction were underplayed in this movie since it highlights a story of a single family. These and worse atrocities were committed to thousands of other innocent families. Some survivors lost as many as 15 family members (mostly men). Their homes and personal belongings were pillaged, women were raped (as a result, many got pregnant and gave birth to babies that carry their abusers' genes), men of all ages were executed (including teenage boys and 70+ year olds), kids were orphaned and families destroyed for generations. And all of this happened in the heart of Europe with the whole world watching....... All of this happened less than a 13-15 hour drive from Rome and Vienna..... both booming with tourists in that hot summer of ‘95. Never forget the Srebrenica genocide! One human life lost is too many, let alone 8000+. May they all Rest In Peace.

The Srebenica Massacre of 1995 was one of the most horrific incidents of the Bosnian War, and the chilling events that led up to it as it played out are presented in unsettling detail in this superb, if troubling, historical account. Told from the perspective of a UN interpreter who struggles to find safety for her family during the crisis, the film follows the ordeals of Muslim refugees fleeing the onslaught of merciless Serb militants and the United Nations' inability and ineptitude in providing the protection promised them. Director Jasmila Zbanic's latest puts viewers in the middle of the unfolding genocide, re-creating the horror and anguish experienced by those caught up in it without ever becoming graphic or gratuitous but nevertheless palpably unnerving. The excellent ensemble cast, led by the award-worthy performance of Jasna Djuricic as the desperate protagonist, sell this story so effectively that one can't help but feel what they and their peers are going through. "Quo Vadis, Aida?" will undoubtedly leave audiences uncomfortable and heartbroken, but it brings to light the unspeakable atrocities that occurred during this conflict in hopes that we never experience it again.
A very emotional movie about the attrocities that happened in the UN Safe Zone Srebrenica. Jasna Đuričić played the role of her life. Oscarworthy!

rt_summary: Bosnia, July 11th 1995. Aida is a translator for the United Nations in the small town of Srebrenica. When the Serbian army takes over the town, her family is among the thousands of citizens looking for shelter in the UN camp. As an insider to the negotiations Aida has access to crucial information that she needs to interpret. What is at the horizon for her family and people -- rescue or death? Which move should she take?
